express.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to tell or show what you are feeling or thinking by using words, looks, or actions
express.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: Parents have expressed their concerns about their children’s safety.
She expressed an interest in seeing York.
Many people have expressed their opposition to the proposals.
Words can’t express (=it is impossible to describe) how angry we felt.
Bill’s not afraid to express his opinions.
She doesn’t express her emotions as much as he does.
Finally, I’d like to express my sincere thanks to all those who have helped today.
The USA expressed reservations before agreeing to sign the agreement.
Express your reasons for applying in simple terms.
Young children often have difficulty expressing themselves.
He first learnt to express himself through movement at his dance classes.
express.translation[0].definitions[1].de: to show or describe a particular feeling
express.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: Many of Munch’s paintings express a deep feeling of despair.
express.translation[0].definitions[2].de: to change an amount or quantity into a different form, especially in mathematics
express.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: The value of the coffee becomes significantly higher when expressed in foreign currency.
express.translation[0].definitions[3].de: if a woman expresses milk, she presses milk out of her breast in order to feed it to her baby later
express.translation[0].note_box[0].secti: express your views/opinions/ideas
Everyone who attends the meeting will be given the opportunity to express their opinions.
express your feelings
He felt unable to express his feelings in a letter.
express an interest in something
Many property developers have expressed an interest in buying the land.
express concern
Financial analysts have expressed concern about the possibility of a recession.
express your thanks/gratitude/appreciation
On behalf of the team, I’d like to express our appreciation for all your efforts.
express doubts/reservations
Environmentalists began to express doubts about the benefits of biofuels.
express surprise/shock
‘I don’t believe he could hurt anyone, ’ she said, expressing her surprise.
express anger
Teachers have expressed anger at the government’s education reforms.
express your grief
She searched for further words to express her grief, but could find none.
express your sympathy
I wrote to his widow expressing our sympathy and sending her our condolences.
express confidence
Throughout the trial, his legal team expressed confidence in the outcome.
express your hopes/desires
Nadia expressed her hopes about remaining in San Diego County with her two children.
express your support
The Israeli leader expressed his support for the U.S. plan.
express opposition to something
Local people have expressed their opposition to plans for a new airport.
express a willingness to do something
The unions expressed a willingness to have talks with the employers.
express something openly
They expressed their anger openly in the meeting.
express something clearly
He expresses his views very clearly.
express yourself
He is very confident and finds it easy to express himself.
a chance/opportunity to express something
The debate will give MPs an opportunity to express their views in detail.
words cannot express something
Words can’t express how much I miss her.
express.translation[1].definitions[0].de: deliberate and for a specific situation
express.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: The school was founded with the express purpose of teaching deaf children.
express.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: Matthew left express instructions to keep all doors locked.
He is not to leave without my express permission.
express.translation[1].definitions[2].de: designed to help you move through a place more quickly
express.translation[1].definitions[2].ex: an express line at a supermarket  (=where people with only a few things to buy go to pay)
express.translation[2].definitions[0].de: a train or bus that does not stop in many places and therefore travels quickly
express.translation[2].definitions[0].no: London–Gatwick Express/Orient Express (=a fast train or bus which does a particular journey regularly)
express.translation[2].definitions[1].de: a post service that delivers letters and packages very quickly
express.translation[4].definitions[0].de: a British daily tabloid newspaper which usually supports the ideas of the Conservative Party
express.translation[5].definitions[0].de: to say what you think or feel about something
express.translation[5].definitions[0].ex: The sales manager expressed caution about the deal.
The USA expressed reservations before eventually signing the agreement.
Worries have been expressed within the industry about a rise in interest rates.
express.translation[5].definitions[1].de: to state clearly and openly something that has been agreed
express.translation[5].definitions[1].ex: Such warranties are implied, unless a contract expresses a contrary intention.
express.translation[5].definitions[2].de: to write a quantity or amount in numbers, letters, or other figures
express.translation[5].definitions[2].ex: The country’s level of expenditure is expressed as a percentage of the measure of economic activity.
The value of the coffee becomes significantly higher when expressed in foreign currency.
express.translation[6].definitions[0].de: stated or written clearly and openly, and showing a clear purpose or intention
express.translation[6].definitions[0].ex: the distinction between express authority and mere consent
Copyright prevents use of this material without theexpress permission of the author.
There is an express agreement by the plaintiff to pay £10 towards the ground-rent.
express.translation[6].definitions[1].de: an express service is one that is quicker than the normal service
express.translation[6].definitions[1].ex: It takes anything from 2 to 5 days, depending on whether or not you use an express transfer.
